Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Growth, immune function, and the energetics of childhood

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Childhood is a unique and developmentally critical life stage within the human genus. While theory concerning the evolution of the human life cycle now abounds, biocultural data from traditional, non-industrialized populations are scarce, and relatively little is known about how children in such challenging environments behave, respond to environmental stimuli, or manage limited energetic resources. This study by doctoral student Samuel Urlacher (Harvard), under the guidance of Dr. Peter Ellison, builds upon scholarship in diverse areas of anthropology, biology, and public health to address two questions that are critical to our understanding of human life history and adaptation: 1) How is childhood growth related to the function of the immune system? 2) How do children 'buffer' energetic tradeoffs between competing metabolic demands? To investigate these questions, this research operationalizes hypotheses relating to childhood energy allocation and phenotypic plasticity among the traditional-living Shuar of the Ecuadorian Amazon.

Innovative in design, the project involves longitudinal data collection for measures of short-term linear growth, body composition, physical activity/behavior, and a diverse set of biomarkers of immune function with children age 5-10. This study is unique in its ability to control for differences in individual biology and is the first to consider multiple branches of immunity and physical activity as important variables in childhood energy management. Employing a novel method for short-term growth assessment (knemometry), the research also provides insight into previously unexplored relationships between primary human life functions and acute ecological/energetic variables.

In addition to increasing our broad-based understanding of human health, adaptation, and the importance of energy management in the evolution of childhood, the project has implications for multiple areas of research and application to issues of childhood development and well-being on a global scale. As part of the Shuar Health and Life History Project, this research builds on a strong foundation of international collaboration and community outreach. Results from the study are shared with Ecuadorian officials and will directly influence the development of health policy and the targeting of humanitarian aid in Shuar territory. Essential to any research with at-risk populations, the project also shares information with participants' families and delivers basic health education at the community level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project employed evolutionary theory and innovative field and laboratory methods to investigate the energetics of childhood among the small-scale, indigenous Shuar of Amazonian Ecuador. It addressed two primary research questions that are critical to our understanding of human biology, adaptation, and health: 1) How is childhood linear growth related to diverse forms of immune activity under challenging environmental conditions? 2) How do some children overcome energy shortfalls to avoid facing tradeoffs between competing metabolic demands during times of energetic stress? Hypotheses relating to these questions were tested using a longitudinal study design incorporating novel repeat measures of weekly linear growth, body fat, and a diverse panel of biomarkers of immune function (including measures of Epstein-Barr virus [EBV] antibodies, a critically understudied measure of cell-mediated immunity).

Project Intellectual Merit: This project has resulted in several key outcomes that contribute to scientific knowledge. It has provided arguably the strongest evidence to date supporting the existence of energetic tradeoffs between childhood growth and immune function, demonstrating that elevated immune activity results in as much as 64% reduction in childhood growth. It has further shown that 1) tradeoffs between growth and specific branches of immunity are unequal; 2) the strength of tradeoffs is highly dependent upon the temporal similarity of growth and immune measures, with short-term (i.e. weekly) measures demonstrating the strongest relationships; and 3) body fat plays an important role in mediating tradeoffs, such that children with ample body fat are able to rapidly draw upon these energy reserves to continue to grow during periods of elevated immune activity. As such, this project represents significant advances in the study of biological anthropology, human biology, immunology, and evolutionary ecology. Chiefly, it provides significant support for the validity of popular life history theory models and suggests that human energetic tradeoffs and phenotypic plasticity may play out over short-term intervals of days rather than months or years as typically conceptualized. This has important implications for understandings of human evolution, adaptation, and health, implying that the evolution of childhood as a unique life stage in our species may be related to acute energetic challenges faced early in life. In addition to these theoretical contributions, this project has resulted in important methodological advances. These include the development of a portable device to measure childhood short-term linear growth in the field and the validation of a new laboratory assay for measuring EBV antibodies in minimally invasive dried blood spot samples. Findings from this project are being shared at scientific conferences and in peer-reviewed publications.

Project Broader Impacts: This project has also resulted in significant broader impacts. It has provided substantial opportunity for training and professional development, including training in study design, laboratory methods, data analysis, and manuscript preparation for the award recipient (a graduate student) as well as four undergraduate students, two of whom are female. It has additionally involved direct health training for participating Shuar communities through public lectures on various topics (e.g., growth, nutrition, physical activity, and personal hygiene). Preliminary project data and results have been shared with Shuar and Ecuadorian officials and are currently being used to identify primary childhood health risks and develop effective targeted relief aid among the Shuar and other local indigenous populations.
